_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Foam System,Structural Integrity Program, Double Containment Tank Construction, STAN Reporting System
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Installation of Berm around tank, STAN Call System
_prev_prog_3.Description:
This process includes  an atmospheric storage tank, refrigeration and heating systems, flare, ammonia bullets, vaporizer, and transfer pumps.
 -  The PHA for the ammonia refrigeration system is the  latest PHA performed. The PHA for the ammonia storage and handling system was last updated on 09/05/02. The PHA reported is for a new ammonia refrigeration unit started up in December 2003.
- The double containment tank indicated is the atmospheric storage tank which is a double wall, double integrity tank with the annulus monitored continously for ammonia leakage. Also a new berm has been installed  December 2003.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fusible Plugs To Isolate Vessel during fire.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZMAT Team, STAN Call System
_prev_prog_3.Description:
This process is the acrylonitrile (ACRN) production plant. The process makes hydrocyanic acid (HCN) as a coproduct and includes the storage tanks for ACRN and HCN as well as the propylene storage tanks and feed system. Propylene is a raw material for the process. Everything in this prevention plan applies to all the units, with the following exceptions:
- The ACRN production plant is separated into systems for the purpose of performing PHA studies to spread the PHA load over five years. The PHA information shown is for the most recent PHA performed on the Propylene storage system (12/14/03). The dates of the other pertinent PHA's are 12/31/01 - HCN storage, 6/24/03 - ACRN plant reaction system, 12/31/00 - ACRN recovery system, and 12/31/99 - ACRN purification and ACRN storage.  
- The HCN and ACRN detectors apply only for HCN and ACRN respectively, and are used as both process area detectors and perimeter monitors.
- The propylene detectors apply only to propylene and are used as perimeter monitors.
- The sprinkler system is not used in the ACRN storage area.
- The foam system is only used in the ACRN storage area.
- The flare pistol is only used to mitigate HCN releases.
- The deluge system, water monitors, are only used at the propylene tank farm.
- Scrubbers are only used in ACRN service on the ACRN storage tank vents, and on Hydroquinone (HQ) and Methyl Ether of Hydroquinone (MEHQ) make up tanks.
- All relief valves for toxics and flammables in the ACRN plant and the HCN storage area are routed to a flared vent system except for the ammonia feed system and propylene feed piping and storage system.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Flare Pistol for firing HCN spills, HAZMAT Response Team, STAN Call System, HCN Cars Double Walled
_prev_prog_3.Description:
This process is the on-site storage of hydrogen cyanide (HCN) and acrylonitrile (ACRN) in rail cars for inventory control. In the case of HCN, material is loaded and stored in rail cars designed for HCN shipping when our on-site customer is shutdown for an extended period for routine or emergency maintenance and repairs. HCN is a coproduct of the ACRN plant and it is not always possible to match the production requirements for HCN and ACRN. When the plant using the HCN is back on line, the HCN stored in rail cars is unloaded into the HCN storage tanks feeding the customer's plant.
In the case of ACRN, material is loaded and stored in rail cars designed to ship ACRN when a barge tow is late, the storage tanks are full, and there are no orders for rail car shipments.  Material is stored until the barge tow arrives and is loaded and there is room in the storage tank. Then the ACRN is unloaded into the ACRN storage tank.
Rail car storage of ACRN and HCN is not a process in the sense that a manufacturing plant or operating unit is a process. The material is loaded into rail cars just as if it was to be shipped off site. However, the rail cars are moved to the east and west ends of the plant, inside the fenceline, for storage until the material can be unloaded back into the respective storage tanks. The rail car storage is treated the same as a process, however, in that the site process safety mangement systems are used in managing and operating the storage.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Ton Container Fusible Plugs in the event of fire. Containers designed to expand if overpressured.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained Site HAZMAT team, water fog, emergency repair kits
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process is a water treatment plant that uses chlorine as part of the process to convert raw water to treated water for potable water.  The chlorine storage and injection system is the only PHA for the process.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: 40CFR60 Air Rules, TCEQ 30 TAC Texas Admin. Code

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DUPONT BEAUMONT WORKS RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
At the DuPont Beaumont Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all our processes in a safe and responsible manner. Our plant adheres to the DuPont Corporate policies, which are summarized as follows:
       > All Safety and Environmental incidents are preventable
       > The Goal is Zero - Zero Incidents Period
       > All employees and contractors are responsible for their safety.
The DuPont Corporate policies are embodied in numerous Safety, Health and Environmental (SHE) and Engineering Standards, which apply globally.  At the Beaumont Plant, the policies are implemented through the Beaumont SHE manual called "Safety How". This manual is available to all site employees via the computer intranet system. Safety How Volume III in particular deals with Process Safety Management systems and requirements and contains the complete Emergency Response Plan for the Beaumont site.

FACILITY DESCRIPTION
Our facility is located on Highway 347 between the cities of Beaumont and Nederland, Texas. The DuPont Beaumont site consists of two manufacturing processes: An Acrylonitrile Plant and an Aniline plant. The products from these plants are Acrylonitrile (ACRN), Hydrocyanic Acid (HCN), Acetonitrile Azeotrope and Aniline. The following regulated substances are produced, or used as raw materials, intermediates or additives:
Regulated Toxics - Anhydrous ammonia, Acyrlonitrile (ACRN), Hydrocyanic acid (HCN), Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), and Chlorine
Regulated Flammable- Propylene

KEY OFF SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS
WORST CASE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIOS
The worst case release scenario for a toxic chemical is the failure of Hydrocyanic acid tank cars at either the west or east ends of the plant. The maximum capacity of the tank cars are 100,000 lbs, with no mitigation assumed. This release has off site impact, as determined by the use of the OCA Guidance. This releas

e is highly unlikely due to the high-integrity design of the tank cars including a double wall, security measures on site, and emergency responce.
WORST CASE FLAMMABLE SCENARIO
The worst case release scenario for a flammable chemical is the failure of a single propylene storage bullet. Amount released is 298,000 lbs. The entire content is released in 10 minutes and assumed to vaporize and ignite. The release has no off site impact. No mitigation is assumed. There are propylene detectors and water cannons surrounding the storage area and remotely operated shut off valves.
ALTERNATE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIOS
Anhydrous Ammonia - An Anhydrous Ammonia pipe (3" diam) ruptures. The release rate is 7680 lbs./min based on RMP-Comp estimation. The release was assumed to last 10 minutes before valves can be closed. The presence of perimeter leak detectors and emergency response was assumed. This release has off site impact as determined using RMP-Comp. 
Hydrocyanic Acid - A 2 inch pipe is ruptured. The release rate of 800 lbs./min. is based on DuPont's estimation of HCN evaporation from a pool.  Dupont estimates were used due to the unique properties of HCN boiling pools.  There are HCN sensors located throughout the HCN handling areas, so a leak will be detected and located quickly. The release duration used was 5 minutes due to remote shut-off valves. This scenario has off site impact as determined using the dense vapor dispersion tables.
Acrylonitrile - A 3 inch line ruptures. The release rate of 16,200 lbs./min was calculated based on RMP-Calc's pipe leak utility. A release duration of 10 minutes was assumed until valves can be closed. No active mitigation was assumed. The vapor release rate was calculated to be 7680 lbs./min based on the evaporation rate from the pool. This scenario has off site impact as determined using RMP-Calc.
Sulfur Dioxide - A storage tank relief valve passes 71 lbs/min of SO2 vapor for 10 minutes with no offsite impacts.
Chlorine - The 1 inch diamet

er fusible fire plug failure for a one ton chlorine cylinder releasing 283 lbs./min. for 7 minutes (at which point the cylinder is empty). The release is detected by operator patrols, the operations area responds in full acid suits with SCBA and repairs the cylinder with a ton container repair kit. No other mitigation was assumed. This release has no off site impact as determined using RMP-Comp.
Alternate Flammable Release Scenarios
Propylene - A propylene storage tank BLEVE with offsite impact. This off-site impact is restricted to the Neches River and does not affect any residential areas.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
DuPont Beaumont operations follows the requirements of DuPont Corporate SHE Standard S21A, "Process Safety Management". This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68. Our safety management systems address all the key features of successful prevention programs including:
Designing for Safety...
- A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis and process design basis.
- Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded
- Materials of construction are selected to provide mechanical integrity
- Process hazards reviews are conducted at several stages of the design process
- Quality assurance ensures fabrication according to design specifications and proper assembly
- Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.
Operating Safely...
- Operators are trained and job qualified.
- Operators follow approved written procedures.
- Technical resources are available and utilized as required.
- The site is fenced and patroled. All visitors are logged in and out at the gate and logged in and out at the areas they visit.
Maintaining Our Plants
- Maintenance personnel are trained and qualified.
- Contractors are trained and qualified.
- A hot work permit system controls hazards.
- Safety critical equipment is set up on a periodi

c, appropriate inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.
- Quality assurance ensures the correct replacement materials are used for maintenance and repairs.
- A management of change system is in place to review safety aspects of all changes.
Auditing Our Operations...
- Process hazards analyses are conducted routinely by experienced PHA teams.
- Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted before starting any new or modified equipment.
- Routine safety inspections are conducted.
- Corporate, independent, governmental and internal audits of our systems are conducted.
- All incidents are investigated and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. We have experienced no known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage from a release of any of the regulated chemicals in the last five years.  However, an incident with Hydrocyanic acid occurred in 1999 in which two Dupont employees were exposed to HCN.  These two injuries were classified as Medical Treatment Cases and recorded on the OSA 300 Log.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Beaumont DuPont facility maintains a comprehensive, integrated Emergency Response program that includes a written plan which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. The DuPont facility is a participant in the Beaumont Industrial Park Emergency Response Team. This 70 member plus team is trained to the HAZ-MAT Technician level for chemical response and Advanced Interior and Exterior level for fire fighting. The Emergency Response Team also has members trained and certified as EMTs and Confined Space Rescue technicians. Emergency response plans are current. The Beaumont Industrial Park has an emergency alarm system that consists of in-plant horns and bells. The community is alerted through

the LEPC and the STAN call down system, which uses the Federal Emergency Alerting system. Local emergency responders are notified whenever the site Emergency Response Team is committed to perform actual emergency response operations. The Emergency Response program is coordinated with the local community response plan. Beaumont facility personnel actively participate in the Jefferson County Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Sabine Neches Chiefs Association. The Industrial Park excercises its plan annually and also participates in county wide drills staged by the LEPC and other local emergency response organizations. Critiques are held on drills and actual events and the findings are used to improve site plans and procedures. The Beaumont Industrial Park program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The following is a list of improvements that we are planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:
         - Continued focus on "The Goal is Zero" for injuries and incidents.
         -Strive for continuous improvements through use of inherently safer process implementation.

 CERTIFICATIONS
For all the Beaumont DuPont covered processes the undersigned also certifies that, to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted in this RMP plan is true, accurate and complete.

Jim Ellis
Site Manager
